title: 104_hr2439
content: The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" allows states to use State infrastructure banks for financing transportation projects, providing more freedom in developing low-cost support for public-private transportation partnerships. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" defines key terms such as Secretary, State, and State infrastructure bank. State infrastructure banks are created at the State or multi-State level to finance transportation projects. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" grants consent to States to establish State infrastructure banks through interstate compacts to promote regional investment in transportation infrastructure. These banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to entities for eligible transportation projects under federal laws. State infrastructure banks established under the "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" can provide loans or assistance to public or private entities for transportation projects eligible for financial aid under federal laws. Assistance may include credit enhancements, capital reserves, or subordinated debt financing. Assistance for qualifying projects under this Act can be subordinated to other debt financing. "Other assistance" includes credit enhancements, capital reserves, bond issuance costs, insurance, interest rate subsidies, and other approved leveraging tools. States must maintain an investment grade rating for their infrastructure banks to qualify under this section. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, each participating State must maintain an investment grade rating on its debt issuances or have sufficient insurance. Investment income generated by the bank must be credited to the bank, available for loans to transportation projects, and invested in US Treasury securities. The funds deposited into the bank will be credited, available for loans to transportation projects, and invested to earn interest. Repayment of loans can be credited back to the bank. Loans from the bank will bear positive interest as determined appropriate. The loan repayment terms include crediting repayments to the bank, bearing positive interest, starting repayment within 5 years of project completion, having a maximum 30-year repayment term, and limiting loan amounts to what the State transfers. The Secretary must ensure that loan repayment terms do not exceed 30 years, limit loan amounts to what the State transfers, and require the bank to report annually. Additionally, the Secretary must oversee Federal disbursements for capital reserves and establish procedures for State infrastructure bank loans. The Secretary must oversee Federal disbursements for capital reserves at historic rates and establish procedures for State infrastructure bank loans. States can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds to the bank and disburse them accordingly. Federal funds allocated under specific sections of the title can be transferred to a State infrastructure bank, but not suballocated funds. The transfer must adhere to traditional disbursement rates. Depositing funds into the bank does not create any obligation on the part of the United States, and any issued securities must explicitly state this. The State infrastructure bank does not create any obligation on the United States, and securities issued must explicitly state this. Federal funds used as a capital reserve are exempt from certain management regulations. States can contribute up to 2% of Federal funds deposited for bank administration costs.
